./.title: Introduction
./.body: Welcome to Cadasta's FAQ. Please search for your question:

intro_to_itemtypes/.title: Introduction to Item Types
intro_to_itemtypes/.body:
üîºRemember: ‚ÄúIntroduction to Your Account‚Äù
User Account Information

    
    Login page
    https://www.arcgis.com/home/signin.html 
  



Sign In with username and password at the url

Your home page will be the User Group page
 Select Training Demo - Cadasta

Content will be found within the group

Content can be filtered in various ways

Sign Out of your account by selecting your User Account name in the top-left of your screen



 

Navigate to Content 



See Item Types in the Sidebar


Select item type Maps
Note:     There are two sub-item types (1) Web Maps and (2) Map Files


Select item sub-type Web Maps
Note:     There are no Map Files sub-type in the demo group and are not covered in this 
documentation.

 

Select Web Map Project Rose Field Collector Map


Click Open in Map Viewer


Navigate back to User Group Content and Select Web Map Project Rose Map - Access 
to Electricity


Click Open in Map Viewer

 

Navigate to Content 



See Item Types in the Sidebar


Select item type Layers
Note:     There are seven sub-item types (1) Feature Layers, (2) Tile Layers, (3) Map 
Imager Layers, (4) Imagery Layers, (5) Scene Layers, (6) Tables, and (7) Layer 
Files




Select item sub-type Feature Layers
Note:     This documentation only covers Feature Layers.


Select Feature Layer Project Rose Field Collector PLPd


Click Open in Map Viewer


Navigate back to User Group Content and Select Feature Layer Project Rose QA 
  View


Click Open in Map Viewer


Navigate back to User Group Content and Select Feature Layer Project Rose Survey


Click Open in Map Viewer


Navigate to Content 



See Item Types in the Sidebar


Select item type Apps
Note:     There are three sub-item types (1) Web Apps, (2) Mobile Apps, and (3) Desktop 
Apps


Select item sub-type Web Apps
Note:    There are no Mobile App or Desktop App sub-types in the demo group and are 
not covered in this documentation.    


Select Web App Project Rose Dashboard - Overview


Click View Dashboard    


See Dashboard Details by selecting a collected record‚Äôs polygon


Navigate back to Content and Select Web App Project Rose Dashboard - QA 
Dashboard


Click View Dashboard    


See Dashboard Details by selecting a collected record‚Äôs point


Navigate back to Content and Select Web App Project Rose Dashboard - Resource 
 Metrics


Click View Dashboard    


See Dashboard Details by selecting a collected record‚Äôs polygon(s)
Note: This dashboard has the possibility of one or more manual selections at one time.



Other Item Types not covered in this documentation are:
Scenes

Tools

Files

create_webmap/.title: Creating an Online Map
create_webmap/.body:
üîºRemember: ‚ÄúHow To: Introduction to Your Account‚Äù
User Account Information

    
    Login page
    https://www.arcgis.com/home/signin.html 
  



Sign In with username and password at the url

Your home page will be the User Group page
 Select Training Demo - Cadasta

Content will be found within the group

Content can be filtered in various ways

Sign Out of your account by selecting your User Account name in the top-left of your screen



üîºRemember: ‚ÄúHow To: Introduction to Item Types‚Äù

Navigate to Content 

See Item Types in the Sidebar

Select item type Maps
 Note:     There are two sub-item types (1) Web Maps and (2) Map Files

Select item sub-type Web Maps
 Note:     There are no Map Files sub-type in the demo group and they are not covered in this 
documentation.

Select Web Map Project Rose Field Collector Map

Click Open in Map Viewer

Navigate back to User Group Content and Select Web Map Project Rose Map - Access to 
 Electricity

Click Open in Map Viewer

Navigate to Content 

See Item Types in the Sidebar

Select item type Layers
Note:     There are seven sub-item types (1) Feature Layers, (2) Tile Layers, (3) Map 
Imager Layers, (4) Imagery Layers, (5) Scene Layers, (6) Tables, and (7) Layer 
Files

Select item sub-type Feature Layers
Note:     This documentation only covers Feature Layers.

Select Feature Layer Project Rose Field Collector PLP

Click Open in Map Viewer

Navigate back to User Group Content and Select Feature Layer Project Rose QA 
  View

Click Open in Map Viewer

Navigate back to User Group Content and Select Feature Layer Project Rose Survey

Click Open in Map Viewer

Navigate to Content 

See Item Types in the Sidebar

Select item type Apps
Note:     There are three sub-item types (1) Web Apps, (2) Mobile Apps, and (3) Desktop 
Apps

Select item sub-type Web Apps
Note:    There are no Mobile App or Desktop App sub-types in the demo group and they are 
not covered in this documentation.    

Select Web App Project Rose Dashboard - Overview

Click View Dashboard    

See Dashboard Details by selecting a collected record‚Äôs polygon

Navigate back to Content and Select Web App Project Rose Dashboard - QA Dashboard

Click View Dashboard    

See Dashboard Details by selecting a collected record‚Äôs point

Navigate back to Content and Select Web App Project Rose Dashboard - Resource 
  Metrics

Click View Dashboard    

See Dashboard Details by selecting a collected record‚Äôs polygon(s)
Note: This dashboard has the possibility of one or more manual selections at one time.


Other Item Types not covered in this documentation are:

Scenes


Tools


Files




üîºRemember: ‚ÄúIntroduction to Map Viewer‚Äù

Navigate to the Map Viewer by clicking Map from the top bar

You can navigate to the Map Viewer from any Feature Layer item details page by clicking Open in Map Viewer

See the My Map page overview

The Home button allows you to navigate back to the main ArcGIS Online (AGOL) navigation options

Select Details to navigate to About, Content, and Legend sections.

Select Content to view layers (and Layer Options)

Select the Layer Options to access Show Legend, Show Table, Change Style, 
Filter, Perform Analysis, and More Options

Select the Legend to view layers in their symbolized form

Select Add to add layers to a map

There are multiple options for adding data layers to the map: Search for Layers, Browse Living Atlas Layers, Add Layer from Web, Add Layer from File, and Add Map Notes

Select Basemap to choose a basemap

Navigate to Zoom In, Zoom Out, and Home location by using the Navigation Console

Save your map by selecting Save

Share your map by selecting Share



 
Add a Basemap

Navigate to ArcGIS Online (AGOL) and click Map at the top of the page.

At the top of the Details pane, click the Content button.




If necessary, click the Basemap button on the ribbon and choose a basemap.
Save your map. On the ribbon, click the Save button and choose Save.
 

Add Layers

On the ribbon, click the Add button and choose Search for Layer
  
 A default list of search results appears.

If necessary, click the dropdown arrow at the top of the pane and choose __.
Type in the search box. 
You are able to limit the search results.
In the list of results, locate your search result.
Click Add to add the layer to the map.
You can add as many layers as you would like.
At the top of the search pane, click the Back button.
The layers are drawn, with their default symbols, in the order in which they were loaded into the map.
Save your map. On the ribbon, click the Save button and choose Save.
 

Set Layer Properties

In the Contents pane, point to your layer. Click the More Options button and choose Rename.
In the Rename window, change the layer name and click OK.
In the same way, rename each of your other layers.
In the Contents pane, point to one of your layers. Click the More Options button and click Move up.
The layer moves up one position.
Move the layer to the top of the list.
In the Contents pane, point to the your layer. Click the More Options button and choose Create Labels.
Each entity is labeled.
In the Label Features pane, you can change the label size.
Open the properties for on of the layers and choose Transparency. 
Set the transparency percentage.
Save your map. On the ribbon, click the Save button and choose Save.
 

Define the Map Legend

At the top of the Contents pane, click the Legend button.
Legend entries are created for all layers except the basemap.
At the top of the Legend pane, click the Content button.
Open the properties for a layer and choose Hide in Legend.
 

Keep it hidden if you would like.

If you would like to show the layer, then choose Show in Legend.
 

View the legend again to see the effect, and then go back to the Contents pane.
 


Change a Symbol

In the Contents pane, point to a desired layer and click the Change Style button.
 

In the Change Style pane, the currently selected style is Location (Single symbol), which is indicated by the check mark.
 In this style, all features in the layer are drawn with the same symbol. The Location style is appropriate when you want to see the features on the map but you're not interested in their particular characteristics, such as names or speed limits.

For a drawing style, under Location (Single symbol), click Options.
Under Showing Location Only, click Symbols to change the symbol.
On the color palette, choose a color that you think will look good and click OK.
The new color is applied to the map. (If you don't like it, click Symbols again to open the color palette and choose a different color.)
At the bottom of the Change Style pane, click OK and click Done.
Save your map. On the ribbon, click the Save button and choose Save.


 
More Information
Esri Resource Links
Create a new map
Add layers to the map
Set layer properties
Define the map legend
Change a symbol
Notes

If you're in a new session, clicking Map will open a new map. Otherwise, it will open an existing map (the last map you were using). If an existing map opens, click New Map, and choose Create New Map.
If you save the map, the map extent at the time of saving will become the extent used by the Default extent button. It can also be useful to add spatial bookmarks to navigate to particular map locations.
Layer properties are always accessed in the same way: by pointing to the layer name and clicking an appropriate button or clicking the More Options button and choosing the property you want to change.
The usual practice is to put points above lines, and lines above polygons. Points, lines, and polygons are all feature layers: they usually represent discrete geographic objects that have more or less precise locations and boundaries.
Tile layers are images and cannot be manipulated in the same ways as feature layers. They typically represent large, continuous surfaces rather than discrete objects. Tile layers cannot be moved above feature layers in a map.
When you start a new map, or open one of your own saved maps, it opens with the Contents pane showing. When anyone else opens a map created by you, however, it opens with the Legend pane showing. 
A layer's default display settings, including its style and pop-up configuration, are made by its owner. Once you add a layer to your own map, however, you're free to change those settings.

create_survey/.title: Creating a Survey Form
create_survey/.body:
Create a Survey Form

Navigate to http://survey123.esri.com

Sign in using your ArcGIS Online account

Click Create New Survey at the top of the My Surveys page

Under Using The Web Designer, click Get Started

Name your survey in the Name section

Fill out at least one tag in the Tags section

Fill out at least one sentence in the Summary section

Click the thumbnail image

Browse to an image you would like to upload

Click Open
 



Add a Text Question

Click Create

See the Design Page

Add a question by dragging from the Add tab and dropping on the form
 On the right side of the Design page, under the Add tab, commonly asked question types are shown. To add questions to your survey form, drag them from the Add tab and drop them on the form. You will need to interpret which type of question is required for each of the questions on the paper form

Drag a Singleline Question onto your survey

In the survey, click Untitled Question 1

On the right side of the Design page, notice that the Edit tab is active

On the Edit tab, in the Label section, type your question name
 You could enter a hint or default value for this question if you would like.

Under Validation, check the box for This Is A Required Question
 This will ensure that this question MUST be answered and cannot be skipped
 You could set a minimum or maximum character count for this question

Click Save



 
Add a Date Question

Click the Add tab

In the survey, click Untitled Question 2 and verify on the right side of the Design page 
the Edit tab is active

In the Label section, type Date.

Under Default Setting, select Submitting Date
 After you select this option, Survey123 populates the date field with the current date by
default

Under Validation, check the box for This Is A Required Question

View result

Click Save

 
Add a Multiple-Choice Question

Drag the Multiple Choice question onto your form

On your survey, click Untitled Question 3

Check the Add Other Choice box to add the Other option

View result

Accept the defaults for Appearance and Validation

Click Save



Add a Multiline Text Question

Drag the Multiline Text question onto your form

Click Untitled Question 4 on your survey

In the Label section, type Comment

Under Validation, check the box to Set Min./Max. Characters Count
 For Min., type 0
 For Max., type 256
 Entering a maximum character count will prevent excessively long comments
from being entered

Accept the defaults for the other options

Click Save



Add an Image Question

Drag the Image question onto your form

Click Untitled Question 5 on your survey

In the Label section, type your instructions

Accept the defaults for the other options

Click Save



 
Add a GeoPoint Question

Drag a GeoPoint question onto your form

Click Untitled Question 6 on your survey

In the Label section, type your instructions

Click the Settings tab

In the Thank You Screen section, leave the green check and change the text to a thank 
you statement

Click the Appearance tab and select a color theme for your survey layout

Click Save



 
Preview Before Publishing

Click Preview in the lower-right side of the Design page

You can scroll through the survey to ensure your questions are correct

Click the Phone and Tablet buttons on the right side of the preview screen

Click the Close Preview X to return to the Survey Design page

Make edits to your survey if you have any changes to make

Click Save



 
Publish a Survey

Click Publish in the lower-right side of the Design page
 You will be prompted to verify that you want to publish your survey because you cannot
further edit a survey after it is published

Click Publish at the bottom of the prompt window
 You will receive a message that confirms that your survey was published successfully

Click OK to close the message

Navigate to  ArcGIS Online

Sign in

Click Content to view the My Content page
 You will see a feature layer that will be used to store any location information you collect with your survey and a survey item that is the survey form itself. Note where these items are stored

Sign out of your ArcGIS Online account

send_collected_surveys/.title: Sending offline collected surveys
send_collected_surveys/.body:
Connect your mobile device to the internet

Open Survey123

Sign in to your account if need be

Select your survey (this example uses Project Rose Survey)
 Note: There should be a number in the right-hand corner of the survey that reflects the amount collected offline.
 

Select Outbox
 

Select Send
 Note: You will see the collected surveys in this window. If you have collected 10 surveys, you should see 10 records. In this example, only one survey has been collected, therefore there is only one survey record in the queue. You must be connected to the internet in order to perform this last step.

using_a_webapp/.title: Using a Web App
using_a_webapp/.body:
Navigate to the User Group page

Search for or scroll to the Web App

Click on the Web App to navigate to the item details then click on View Application 
 
 
 OR 
 Open the Web App by clicking on the thumbnail
 

See the Web App


You can zoom in and out, go to the home location, navigate to your current location, and start full screen mode by using these buttons
 Note: At any point you can place your mouse over any of the buttons and an 
identification pop-up will name the button




With the Edit  button  you can open the Edit Widget to add, delete, and edit features


With the Smart Editor  button  you can open the Smart Editor Widget to create new features


With the Draw button  you can open the Draw Widget to add polygons, lines, points, and text


With the Share  button  you can open the Share Widget to email the web app link easily


The scale bar looks like this and is in the left-bottom corner of the web app


The attribute table can be seen by pressing Open Attribute Table button 



The Legend button  shows the map‚Äôs legend


The Layer list  buttondisplays the map‚Äôs layers
 

The Print button  provides advanced map output options


See the Advanced option for map layout options


The Add Data  button  allows you to search for more layers in your User Group and to add those or others from your files to the map




Additional Resources
Print Widget
Widget Overview

intro_to_storymap/.title: Introduction to Creating a Story Map
intro_to_storymap/.body:
üîºRemember: ‚ÄúHow To: Introduction to Your Account‚Äù
User Account Information

    
    Login page
    https://www.arcgis.com/home/signin.html 
  



Sign In with username and password at the url

Your home page will be the User Group page
   Select Training Demo - Cadasta

Content will be found within the group

Content can be filtered in various ways

Sign Out of your account by selecting your User Account name in the top-left of your screen



 

From the ArcGIS Online (AGOL) homepage, navigate to the Apps Launcher


Select the Story Maps app


A new internet window will open


Select Create My First Story

Select Map Journal
Note: Map Journal is one of many types of Story Map template types. You can choose whichever one you would like. In this example, a Map Journal template is used.

The Map Journal Builder splash screen appears

Select Side Panel and then Start


The Map Journal Builder screen appears
Note: This is where you will build your Story Map. If you had chosen a Map Tour Story Map template, then it would be called Map Tour Builder.


Type in a title for your Story Map and click the forward button ()


The Add Home Section splash screen appears
Note: This is where you will add content to your story map. You will have the option to add one or more sections.
This Main Stage content page is the first thing your audience will see. Subsequent content sections must be navigated to


Under Map map drop-down choose Select a map


In the next drop down, select My Organization


Select the Access to Water map


Click Next


The Side Panel Content splash screen appears
Note: This is where you can add multimedia content that will show up on the left of your Map


Click Add


Here is the first section you just created


Click Add Section


A new section‚Äôs content splash screen appears



Repeat the same process again as done in content section one



Here is result of section two, ‚ÄúAccess to Electricity‚Äù


Click Save


You can tell your Story Map has been saved by the difference in the top-right corner





Here is your saved Story Map
Note: It has not been shared


Click Share




The Share splash screen will appear
Note: It is set to Private


Click Show story content to see the following
Note: There are No issues found and it is Publically shared


Navigate back to the Story Maps window

You will see your new Story Map in the stories section


Click on your new Story Map‚Äôs title to see additional options
Note: The Story Map title in this example is Project Rose: A Story Map


Navigate back to ArcGIS Online (AGOL)

Click Content and My Content
Note: You will see your new Story Map in My Content


Click your new Story Map to see the Item Details Page


Click Share

Select your User Group and click OK
Note: This example uses the Training Demo - Cadasta group



Navigate to your Groups page and you will see your new Story Map in the Contents


Select your new Story Map and it will open a new browser window    


Log out of your account in ArcGIS Online (AGOL) and close all browser windows or tabs 
when complete

add_fl_in_AGOL/.title: Adding a feature layer to AGOL
add_fl_in_AGOL/.body:
After logging into your ArcGIS Online account, press the "Content" tab and then select "My Content"
 

Press the "Add Item" button 




Select the "From my computer" option


See the splash window, Add an item from my computer, appear


Press the "Choose File" button

Navigate to a zipped shapefile folder


Rename and add Tags to the new item
 
 



Press the "Add Item"button
The new layer will show up in the list of items in the "My Content" section. If you want to share this layer with any of the groups that you have access to simply press the "Share" button and select the groups you wish to share with.

add_fl_to_collectormap/.title: Adding a Feature Layer to a Collector Map
add_fl_to_collectormap/.body:
In AGOL, navigate to your Group page


Press the "Content" tab in your Group

 

Find and select your Collector Map (Organization Name)


Press the "Open in Map Viewer" button


See the Map Viewer with the Collector Map (Organization Name)
 

Press the "Add" button 
  

Choose "Search for layers"
Note: There are different options available, including, from file


Type in the name of the layer in the search section.
 Note: examplepolygon was used in this example
  

Select the plus icon to add the layer 
See that the new layer example polygon has been added and is present in the Legend
 

Press the "Save" button

add_fl_to_collector_map/.title: Adding a Feature Layer From a File to a Collector Map
add_fl_to_collector_map/.body:
In AGOL, navigate to your Group page


Press the "Content" tab in your Group

 

Find and select your Collector Map (Organization Name)


Press the "Open in Map Viewer" button


See the Map Viewer with the Collector Map (Organization Name)
 

Press the "Add" button
 

Choose "Add Layer From File"
Note: There are different options available, including, from layers


Press the "Choose File" button.
 Note the rules for files in the splash screen

Navigate to a zipped shapefile folder 
 
Press the "Import Layer" button
 

Symbolize, or stylize, the layer 


Press the "Done" button
 
See the new layer in the Legend

Press the "Save" button

add_img_to_AGOL/.title: Adding a drone image to AGOL/Portal
add_img_to_AGOL/.body:
Open ArcMap or ArcGIS Pro
Open the drone image
Right click the image layer and select Share -> as Web Layer


Select ‚ÄúMap Image‚Äù option

Go to the ‚ÄúConfiguration‚Äù tab and then select the pencil icon next to the image layer


Make sure to slide the ‚Äúlevels of detail‚Äù to its maximum value (level 23)

add_field/.title: Adding a field to a feature layer
add_field/.body:
Navigate to the desired Web Map and press the Item Details button


Press the Open in Map Viewer button


See the Web Map 


Click Content 


Click the Show Table icon  
under the desired layer
 Note: This example uses the Pradan geometry - Polygon layer


See the Table View

Click Options 

Click Add Field
 

Fill out the contents of the field values 
 Note: This example uses double type for its numerical field for area in hectares
 

Click Add New Field

See the new Field in the Table
 Note: This example uses the Hectares field
 

Click on the field name, Hectares

Click on Calculate
 

The Calculate Field window appears

Fill out the SQL Expression
 Expression: POWER(Shape__Area,2)/10000
 Explanation:    The Shape_Area field is in square meters. In order to convert meters to hectares, 
you must base the expression on the following equation: Ha = m2/1,000
 



Click Calculate

See that the Hectares field has been calculated

editing_vertices/.title: Editing Polygon Vertices
editing_vertices/.body:
Navigate to map in Map Viewer

Navigate to your desired polygon


Click the polygon once


Pause for 5 seconds

Click the polygon again


Move the vertex



Click anywhere outside of the polygon


Click Save

delete_vertics_ArcPro/.title: Deleting Vertices in ArcGIS Pro
delete_vertics_ArcPro/.body:
In the "Map" tab, press the "Select" button and then select the polygon you wish to edit
 
Select the "Edit" tab 

In the "Edit" tab, press the "Modify" button

In the "Edit" tab -> "Tools" section, press the "Vertices" button

Press the "Delete" button and the select the vertices in the map that you want to delete

Press the "Finish" button

delete_collected_polygon/.title: Deleting a Collected Survey Polygon
delete_collected_polygon/.body:
Navigate to your User Group



Find the Field Collector Map (Web Map) you used to collect the polygons

Select the Web Map
 

Press the Open in Map Viewer button


See the Map Viewer Overview
 

Select Content


See the Map Viewer Content Sidebar


Hover the mouse over the polygon layer 
 

You will see multiple options. Select Show Table


See Show Table view
 

Click More Options within the table sub-window


Select Show/Hide Columns
 
 

You can toggle columns on and off by checking and unchecking the boxes next to the 
column names
  Note: In this example, only the OBJECTID column is toggled on and showing
 
 
 See when additional columns are toggled on
 

Click More Options


Select Center on Selection
 Note: The Selected Record in this example is OBJECTID 4
 

See OBJECTID 4 Selection in Map Viewer


Click on the selected polygon record to see the associated pop-up


Select Edit in the pop-up to edit the polygon

See the Edit pop-up window
 

Press Delete to delete the selected polygon feature

Press Close to stop editing

join_two_layers/.title: Joining Two Feature Layers
join_two_layers/.body:
Before joining features, please make sure the following has been done:

You are the owner of feature layer 1
You are the owner of feature layer 2
You know which AGOL folder you can access



Navigate to the desired Web Map and press the "Item Details" button


Press the Open in Map Viewer button 

See the Web Map 

Click Analysis 

See Perform Analysis sidebar

Click Summarize Data 

See Summarize Data 


Click Join Features 

See the Join Features Steps


Choose your target layer (layer 1 mentioned in the pre-steps)
 Note: This will be your geometry layer in this example 


Choose your join layer (layer 2 mentioned in the pre-steps)
 Note: This will be your survey layer in this example


Select the Join Type, Choose the fields to match
 Note: This example bases the join on fields (tables) and not on geometry (spatial) 
    

Select the fields to join
 

Select GlobalID (layer 1) 
Select collectorID (layer 2)



Choose Join Operation, Join one to many
 Note: This example uses a one to many relationship but you could use a one to one relationship for other reasons 


Name the join and select the folder to save the join in (remember the folder from the pre-steps)


Uncheck the "Use current map extent" checkbox and check the "Create results as hosted feature layer view"


Click Run Analysis

See your newly created Feature Layer in the Contents sidebar of the Web Map with the other Feature Layers

labeling_features/.title: Adding labels to features in a web map
labeling_features/.body:
Navigate to map in Map Viewer

Select More Options  from the desired layer


Select Create Labels from More Options


See the Label Features window


Choose desired label from the Text drop-down
Note: The drop-down options consist of attributes. A new expression can be created and applied. The expression must be written using Arcade expression language. You can read more about Arcade expressions at this link.


In this example, the CreationDate attribute was chosen in the Text drop-down


Press OK once the labels are set

Click Save


See the end result of the labelled polygons

set_basemap_trans/.title: Setting Basemap Transpancey
set_basemap_trans/.body:
Navigate to the desired Web Map and press the "Item Details" button


Click Open in Map Viewer 


See the Web Map with a visible background image (Basemap Image Layer)
 

Click Content
 

Click the Expand Arrow  of the Basemap Imagery Layer Group  to show the Basemap Layer(s)
 Note: This example uses the Dark Gray Canvas Basemap Imagery Layer Group, which includes the Dark Gray Reference and Dark Gray Base Layers.
 

Click More Options  found under the desired layer
Note: This example shows the Dark Gray Base Layer.
 

Click or hover your mouse over Transparency 


Set Transparency to 100% for any basemap imagery
 

See that there is no longer a basemap present


Click Save

add_webmap_popup/.title: Creating Web Map Pop-Ups
add_webmap_popup/.body:
Navigate to your desired map in the Map Viewer
 

Click More Options  

Click Configure Pop-up 


See the Configure Pop-up sidebar
 

Choose an option from the Display drop-down
 

If you chose A list of field attributes follow these steps:
 

Select Configure Attributes

Check the boxes next to the attributes that you wish to display
  

Press OK

Press OK





If you chose A description from one field follow these steps:


Select the desired attribute from the Attributes drop-down 
Press OK


If you chose A custom attribute display follow these steps:


Click Configure

See Custom Attribute Display window




Fill out content as desired

Press OK

Press OK



If you chose No attribute information follow these steps:


Press OK
Press Save

print_webmap/.title: Printing a Web Map
print_webmap/.body:
Navigate to your desired map in Map Viewer



Select Print


Select Map with Legend


See the output screen


Choose Print from your web browser

export_fl_to_shp/.title: Exporting Feature Layer to Shapefile
export_fl_to_shp/.body:
Note: Exporting is only available for feature layers that you are their owner and that have been marked as "Allow others to export to different format"

Navigate to the desired Feature Layer


Click Export Data


Click Export to Shapefile

 

See Export to Shapefile window


Type in a Title, one or more Tags, and choose a Folder
Note: The folder is on ArcGIS Online and not on your computer or device


Click Export

See the resulting exported file page 


Click Download


The file will download as a zipped file

s123_add_new_lang/.title: Survey123 Adding a new language
s123_add_new_lang/.body:
Open your survey form in Microsoft Excel and navigate to the "Survey" tab 
Scroll over to the second Label column, or field, header
 
 If you do not know the official language or subtag to use, please search for the language from this link: https://www.iana.org/assignments/language-subtag-registry/language-subtag-registry

The second language field header should follow this pattern
 label::Description (subtag)
 For example, for the Indonesian language the syntax would be
 label::Indonesian (id)

Note that the description name upholds proper capitalization, or proper casing, while the subtag is completely uncapitalized 
 Also please note that there is only a space between the description and the open parenthesize
 Here is how the final result would look like:

chg_usr_pwd/.title: AGOL - Changing a User Password
chg_usr_pwd/.body:
Sign in to ArcGIS Online (AGOL)
Select "User Name" in the top-right corner of the page:
   
Select "My Profile"


Select "Edit my profile"


Select "Change Password"


Change password and select "Change Password" in the new screen


Select Save


Sign out of your User account
